content: 1 The words of the Proclaimer､ son of David, king in Jerusalem.
content_old: 1 The words of the Proclaimer､ son of David, king in Jerusalem.

content: 2 Vanity of vanities! saith the Proclaimer, vanity of vanities! all is vanity.
content_old: 2 Vanity of vanities! saith the Proclaimer, vanity of vanities! all is vanity.

content: 3 What profit hath Man,—in all his toil where with he toileth under the sun?
content_old: 3 What profit hath Man,—in all his toil where with he toileth under the sun?

content: 4 Generation goeth and generation cometh, but the earth unto times age-abiding remaineth.
content_old: 4 Generation goeth and generation cometh, but the earth unto times age-abiding remaineth.

content: 5 And the sun breaketh forth､ and the sun goeth in,—yea unto his own place he panteth､ from whence he brake forth.
content_old: 5 And the sun breaketh forth､ and the sun goeth in,—yea unto his own place he panteth､ from whence he brake forth.

content: 6 Going unto the south, and circling unto the north,—circling､ circling continually is the wind, and over its own circuits returneth the wind.
content_old: 6 Going unto the south, and circling unto the north,—circling､ circling continually is the wind, and over its own circuits returneth the wind.

content: 7 All the streams flow into the sea, yet the sea is not full,—unto the place whither the streams flow thither do they again flow.
content_old: 7 All the streams flow into the sea, yet the sea is not full,—unto the place whither the streams flow thither do they again flow.

content: 8 All words are weak, unable is any man to tell,—not satisfied is the eye by seeing, nor filled is the ear with hearing.
content_old: 8 All words are weak, unable is any man to tell,—not satisfied is the eye by seeing, nor filled is the ear with hearing.

content: 9 That which hath been is the same that shall be, and that which hath been done is the same that shall be done,—and there is nothing new under the sun.
content_old: 9 That which hath been is the same that shall be, and that which hath been done is the same that shall be done,—and there is nothing new under the sun.

content: 10 Is’ there a thing､ of which it can be said, See here､ it is new? Already hath it been for ages, it is something which was before us.
content_old: 10 Is’ there a thing､ of which it can be said, See here､ it is new? Already hath it been for ages, it is something which was before us.

content: 11 There is no remembrance of the things before,—nor even of the things after､ which shall be will there be any remembrance, with them who shall come after.
content_old: 11 There is no remembrance of the things before,—nor even of the things after､ which shall be will there be any remembrance, with them who shall come after.

content: 12 I､ the Proclaimer was king over Israel､ in Jerusalem.
content_old: 12 I､ the Proclaimer was king over Israel､ in Jerusalem.

content: 13 And I gave my heart to seek and to search out､ wisely, concerning all things which are done under the heavens,— the same is the vexatious employment God hath given to the sons of men､ to work toilsomely therein.
content_old: 13 And I gave my heart to seek and to search out､ wisely, concerning all things which are done under the heavens,— the same is the vexatious employment God hath given to the sons of men､ to work toilsomely therein.

content: 14 I saw all the works which were done under the sun,—and lo! all was vanity､ and a feeding on wind.
content_old: 14 I saw all the works which were done under the sun,—and lo! all was vanity､ and a feeding on wind.

content: 15 That which is crooked cannot be straight,—and that which is wanting cannot be reckoned.
content_old: 15 That which is crooked cannot be straight,—and that which is wanting cannot be reckoned.

content: 16 Spake I､ in my heart､ saying, As for me lo! I have become great､ and have gathered wisdom, beyond any one who hath been before me over Jerusalem,—and my heart hath seen much wisdom and knowledge:
content_old: 16 Spake I､ in my heart､ saying, As for me lo! I have become great､ and have gathered wisdom, beyond any one who hath been before me over Jerusalem,—and my heart hath seen much wisdom and knowledge:

content: 17 yea I have given my heart､ to know wisdom, and to know madness､ and folly,—I know that even this is a feeding on wind.
content_old: 17 yea I have given my heart､ to know wisdom, and to know madness､ and folly,—I know that even this is a feeding on wind.

content: 1 Said I､ in my heart, Come now! I will prove thee with gladness､ and look thou on blessedness,—but lo! even that was vanity.
content_old: 1 Said I､ in my heart, Come now! I will prove thee with gladness､ and look thou on blessedness,—but lo! even that was vanity.

content: 2 Of laughter I said､ Madness! and of mirth What can it do?
content_old: 2 Of laughter I said､ Madness! and of mirth What can it do?

content: 3 I sought out with my heart, to cherish with wine､ my flesh,—but my heart was to guide with wisdom､ even in laying hold of folly, until I should see which was blessedness for the sons of men､ as to that which they could do､ under the heavens, during the number of the days of their life.
content_old: 3 I sought out with my heart, to cherish with wine､ my flesh,—but my heart was to guide with wisdom､ even in laying hold of folly, until I should see which was blessedness for the sons of men､ as to that which they could do､ under the heavens, during the number of the days of their life.

content: 4 I enlarged my works,—I built me houses, I planted me vineyards;
content_old: 4 I enlarged my works,—I built me houses, I planted me vineyards;

content: 5 I made me gardens､ and parks,—I planted in them trees of every kind of fruit;
content_old: 5 I made me gardens､ and parks,—I planted in them trees of every kind of fruit;

content: 6 I made me pools of water,—to irrigate therefrom the thick-set saplings growing up into trees:
content_old: 6 I made me pools of water,—to irrigate therefrom the thick-set saplings growing up into trees:

content: 7 I acquired､ men-servants and women-servants, and the children of the household were mine,—also possessions､ herds and flocks in abundance were mine, beyond all who had been before me in Jerusalem;
content_old: 7 I acquired､ men-servants and women-servants, and the children of the household were mine,—also possessions､ herds and flocks in abundance were mine, beyond all who had been before me in Jerusalem;

content: 8 I heaped me up､ both silver and gold, and the peculiar treasure of kings､ and provinces,—I provided me singing-men and singing-women, and the delights of the sons of men､ a wife and wives.
content_old: 8 I heaped me up､ both silver and gold, and the peculiar treasure of kings､ and provinces,—I provided me singing-men and singing-women, and the delights of the sons of men､ a wife and wives.

content: 9 So I became great､ and increased, more than any one who had been before me in Jerusalem,—moreover my wisdom remained with me;
content_old: 9 So I became great､ and increased, more than any one who had been before me in Jerusalem,—moreover my wisdom remained with me;

content: 10 and nothing that mine eyes asked withheld I from them,—I did not keep back my heart from any gladness､ for my heart obtained gladness out of all my toil, and so this was my portion､ out of all my toil.
content_old: 10 and nothing that mine eyes asked withheld I from them,—I did not keep back my heart from any gladness､ for my heart obtained gladness out of all my toil, and so this was my portion､ out of all my toil.

content: 11 When I looked upon all my works､ which my hands had made, and on my toil､ whereon I had toilsomely wrought then lo! all was vanity､ I and feeding on wind, and there was no profit under the sun.
content_old: 11 When I looked upon all my works､ which my hands had made, and on my toil､ whereon I had toilsomely wrought then lo! all was vanity､ I and feeding on wind, and there was no profit under the sun.

content: 12 Thus turned I､ to look at wisdom, and madness､ and folly,—for what can the man do more who cometh after the king? save that which already men have done.
content_old: 12 Thus turned I､ to look at wisdom, and madness､ and folly,—for what can the man do more who cometh after the king? save that which already men have done.

content: 13 Then saw I, that wisdom doth excel folly,—as far as light excelleth darkness.
content_old: 13 Then saw I, that wisdom doth excel folly,—as far as light excelleth darkness.

content: 14 As for the wise man his eyes are in his head, whereas the dullard in darkness doth walk,—but I myself knew that one destiny happeneth to them all.
content_old: 14 As for the wise man his eyes are in his head, whereas the dullard in darkness doth walk,—but I myself knew that one destiny happeneth to them all.

content: 15 Then said I､ in my heart, As it happeneth to the dullard even to me will it happen, but wherefore then became I wise to excess? Therefore spake I､ in my heart, Even this is vanity.
content_old: 15 Then said I､ in my heart, As it happeneth to the dullard even to me will it happen, but wherefore then became I wise to excess? Therefore spake I､ in my heart, Even this is vanity.

content: 16 For there is no remembrance of a wise man､ more than of a dullard､ unto times age-abiding,—seeing that already､ in the days to come all hath been forgotten, how then cometh it that the wise man dieth equally with the dullard?
content_old: 16 For there is no remembrance of a wise man､ more than of a dullard､ unto times age-abiding,—seeing that already､ in the days to come all hath been forgotten, how then cometh it that the wise man dieth equally with the dullard?

content: 17 Therefore I hated life, for a vexation unto me was the work which was done under the sun,—for all was vanity､ and a feeding on wind.
content_old: 17 Therefore I hated life, for a vexation unto me was the work which was done under the sun,—for all was vanity､ and a feeding on wind.

content: 18 Therefore hated I all my toil､ wherein I was toiling､ under the sun,—in that I should leave it for the man who should come after me;
content_old: 18 Therefore hated I all my toil､ wherein I was toiling､ under the sun,—in that I should leave it for the man who should come after me;

content: 19 and who could know whether a wise man he would be or a foolish, and yet he would lord it over all my toil､ wherein I had toiled and wherein I had acted wisely､ under the sun,—even this was vanity.
content_old: 19 and who could know whether a wise man he would be or a foolish, and yet he would lord it over all my toil､ wherein I had toiled and wherein I had acted wisely､ under the sun,—even this was vanity.

content: 20 Then resolved I､ to give my heart over to despair,—concerning all the toil, wherein I had toiled､ under the sun.
content_old: 20 Then resolved I､ to give my heart over to despair,—concerning all the toil, wherein I had toiled､ under the sun.

content: 21 For here is a man､ whose toil hath been with wisdom and with knowledge and with skill,—yet to a man who hath not toiled therein shall he leave it as his portion, even this was vanity and a great vexation.
content_old: 21 For here is a man､ whose toil hath been with wisdom and with knowledge and with skill,—yet to a man who hath not toiled therein shall he leave it as his portion, even this was vanity and a great vexation.

content: 22 For what hath the man for all his toil, and for the striving of his heart,—wherein he himself toiled under the sun?
content_old: 22 For what hath the man for all his toil, and for the striving of his heart,—wherein he himself toiled under the sun?

content: 23 For all his days are pains､ and vexatious is his employment, even in the night his heart lieth not down,—even this was vanity.
content_old: 23 For all his days are pains､ and vexatious is his employment, even in the night his heart lieth not down,—even this was vanity.

content: 24 There was nothing more blessed for Man than that he should eat and drink, and see his desire for blessedness in his toil,—even this saw I myself, that from the hand of God it was.
content_old: 24 There was nothing more blessed for Man than that he should eat and drink, and see his desire for blessedness in his toil,—even this saw I myself, that from the hand of God it was.

content: 25 For who could eat and who could enjoy､ so well as I?
content_old: 25 For who could eat and who could enjoy､ so well as I?

content: 1 For every thing there is a season,— And a time for every pursuit､ under the heavens:—
content_old: 1 For every thing there is a season,— And a time for every pursuit､ under the heavens:—

content: 2 A time to be born､
content_old: 2 A time to be born､

content: and a time to die,—
content_old: and a time to die,—

content: A time to plant,
content_old: A time to plant,

content: and a time to uproot what is planted;
content_old: and a time to uproot what is planted;

content: 3 A time to kill､
content_old: 3 A time to kill､

content: and a time to heal,—
content_old: and a time to heal,—

content: A time to break down,
content_old: A time to break down,

content: and a time to build up;
content_old: and a time to build up;

content: 4 A time to weep､
content_old: 4 A time to weep､

content: and a time to laugh,—
content_old: and a time to laugh,—

content: A time to wail,
content_old: A time to wail,

content: and a time to dance for joy;
content_old: and a time to dance for joy;

content: 5 A time to cast away stones､
content_old: 5 A time to cast away stones､

content: and a time to heap up stones,—
content_old: and a time to heap up stones,—

content: A time to embrace,
content_old: A time to embrace,

content: and a time to be far from loving embrace;
content_old: and a time to be far from loving embrace;

content: 6 A time to seek､
content_old: 6 A time to seek､

content: and a time to give up as lost,—
content_old: and a time to give up as lost,—

content: A time to keep,
content_old: A time to keep,

content: and a time to cast away;
content_old: and a time to cast away;

content: 7 A time to rend､
content_old: 7 A time to rend､

content: and a time to sew,—
content_old: and a time to sew,—

content: A time to be silent,
content_old: A time to be silent,

content: and a time to speak;
content_old: and a time to speak;

content: 8 A time to love､
content_old: 8 A time to love､

content: and a time to hate,—
content_old: and a time to hate,—

content: A time of war,
content_old: A time of war,

content: and a time of peace.
content_old: and a time of peace.

content: 9 What profit hath he that worketh, in that wherein himself hath toiled?
content_old: 9 What profit hath he that worketh, in that wherein himself hath toiled?

content: 10 I looked at the employment which God hath given to the sons of men､ to work therein:
content_old: 10 I looked at the employment which God hath given to the sons of men､ to work therein:

content: 11 Everything hath he made beautiful in its own time,—also intelligence hath he put in their heart, without which men could not find out the work which God hath wrought､ from the beginning even unto the end.
content_old: 11 Everything hath he made beautiful in its own time,—also intelligence hath he put in their heart, without which men could not find out the work which God hath wrought､ from the beginning even unto the end.

content: 12 I know that there is no blessedness in them,—save to be glad, and to do well with one’s life.
content_old: 12 I know that there is no blessedness in them,—save to be glad, and to do well with one’s life.

content: 13 Though indeed that any man should eat and drink, and see blessedness､ in all his toil it is the gift of God.
content_old: 13 Though indeed that any man should eat and drink, and see blessedness､ in all his toil it is the gift of God.

content: 14 I know､ that whatsoever God doeth the same shall be age-abiding, unto it there is nothing to add, and from it there is nothing to take away,—and God hath done it, that men should stand in awe before him.
content_old: 14 I know､ that whatsoever God doeth the same shall be age-abiding, unto it there is nothing to add, and from it there is nothing to take away,—and God hath done it, that men should stand in awe before him.

content: 15 That which was already had been, and that which shall be already shall have been,—but God seeketh that which hath been chased away.
content_old: 15 That which was already had been, and that which shall be already shall have been,—but God seeketh that which hath been chased away.

content: 16 Then again I saw under the sun,—the place of justice that there was lawlessness, and the place of righteousness that there was lawlessness.
content_old: 16 Then again I saw under the sun,—the place of justice that there was lawlessness, and the place of righteousness that there was lawlessness.

content: 17 Said I､ in my heart, Both the righteous and the lawless will God judge,—for there will be a time for every pursuit, and concerning every work—there.
content_old: 17 Said I､ in my heart, Both the righteous and the lawless will God judge,—for there will be a time for every pursuit, and concerning every work—there.

content: 18 Said I in my heart, as concerning the sons of men That God was minded to prove them,—and that they might see､ that they were beasts､ of themselves.
content_old: 18 Said I in my heart, as concerning the sons of men That God was minded to prove them,—and that they might see､ that they were beasts､ of themselves.

content: 19 For as regardeth the destiny of the sons of men and the destiny of beasts one fate have they, as dieth the one so dieth the other, and one spirit have they all,—and the pre-eminence of man over beast is nothing, for all were vanitv:
content_old: 19 For as regardeth the destiny of the sons of men and the destiny of beasts one fate have they, as dieth the one so dieth the other, and one spirit have they all,—and the pre-eminence of man over beast is nothing, for all were vanitv:

content: 20 all go unto one place,—all came from the dust, and all return to the dust.
content_old: 20 all go unto one place,—all came from the dust, and all return to the dust.

content: 21 Who knoweth the spirit of the sons of men, whether itascendeth above,—or the spirit of the beast, whether it descendeth below､ to the earth?
content_old: 21 Who knoweth the spirit of the sons of men, whether itascendeth above,—or the spirit of the beast, whether it descendeth below､ to the earth?

content: 1 Then again I considered all the oppressive deeds which were done under the sun,—and lo! the tears of the oppressed､ and they have no comforter, and on the side of their oppressors is power, and they have no comforter.
content_old: 1 Then again I considered all the oppressive deeds which were done under the sun,—and lo! the tears of the oppressed､ and they have no comforter, and on the side of their oppressors is power, and they have no comforter.

content: 2 So I pronounced happy the dead､ who were already dead,—more than the living, who were living still;
content_old: 2 So I pronounced happy the dead､ who were already dead,—more than the living, who were living still;

content: 3 and as better than both him who bad not yet come into being,—who had not seen the vexatious work, which was done under the sun.
content_old: 3 and as better than both him who bad not yet come into being,—who had not seen the vexatious work, which was done under the sun.

content: 4 Then saw I all the toil and all the skill of the work, that for this a man was envied of his neighbour,—even this was vanity､ and a feeding on wind.
content_old: 4 Then saw I all the toil and all the skill of the work, that for this a man was envied of his neighbour,—even this was vanity､ and a feeding on wind.

content: 5 The dullard claspeth his hands, and consumeth his own flesh.
content_old: 5 The dullard claspeth his hands, and consumeth his own flesh.

content: 6 Better′ a handful—with quietness,—than both hands full—with toil､ and feeding on wind.
content_old: 6 Better′ a handful—with quietness,—than both hands full—with toil､ and feeding on wind.

content: 7 Then again I looked at a vain thing under the sun:—
content_old: 7 Then again I looked at a vain thing under the sun:—

content: 8 Here is one､ without a second､ even son or brother he hath none, yet is there no end to all his toil, even his eye is not satisfied with riches,—neither saith he For whom am I toiling､ and letting my soul want good? Even this was vanity､ yea a vexatious employment it was!
content_old: 8 Here is one､ without a second､ even son or brother he hath none, yet is there no end to all his toil, even his eye is not satisfied with riches,—neither saith he For whom am I toiling､ and letting my soul want good? Even this was vanity､ yea a vexatious employment it was!

content: 9 Better are two､ than one,—in that they have a good reward for their toil.
content_old: 9 Better are two､ than one,—in that they have a good reward for their toil.

content: 10 For if the one should fall the other would raise up his companion,—but alas! for him who is alone when he falleth, with no second to raise him up!
content_old: 10 For if the one should fall the other would raise up his companion,—but alas! for him who is alone when he falleth, with no second to raise him up!

content: 11 Moreover if two lie together then have they warmth,—but how can one have warmth?
content_old: 11 Moreover if two lie together then have they warmth,—but how can one have warmth?

content: 12 And though an enemy should prevail against one two might make a stand before him,—and a threefold cord cannot soon be broken.
content_old: 12 And though an enemy should prevail against one two might make a stand before him,—and a threefold cord cannot soon be broken.

content: 13 Better a boy poor and wise,—than a king､ old and stupid, who knoweth not how to take warning any longer.
content_old: 13 Better a boy poor and wise,—than a king､ old and stupid, who knoweth not how to take warning any longer.

content: 14 For out of prison came he forth to reign,—yea even in his own kingdom was he born poor.
content_old: 14 For out of prison came he forth to reign,—yea even in his own kingdom was he born poor.

content: 15 I saw all the living, who were going hither and thither under the sun,—that they were with the boy who was to be the second, who was to stand in the other’s place:—
content_old: 15 I saw all the living, who were going hither and thither under the sun,—that they were with the boy who was to be the second, who was to stand in the other’s place:—

content: 1 Keep thy foot､ when thou goest unto the house of God, and be more ready to hear, than dullards to offer sacrifice,—for they make no acknowledgment of doing wrong.
content_old: 1 Keep thy foot､ when thou goest unto the house of God, and be more ready to hear, than dullards to offer sacrifice,—for they make no acknowledgment of doing wrong.

content: 2 Be not rash with thy mouth､ and with thy heart be not in haste to bring forth a word､ before God,—for God is in the heavens､ and thou upon the earth, for this cause let thy words be few.
content_old: 2 Be not rash with thy mouth､ and with thy heart be not in haste to bring forth a word､ before God,—for God is in the heavens､ and thou upon the earth, for this cause let thy words be few.

content: 3 For a dream cometh through the multitude of business,—and the voice of a dullard is with a multitude of words.
content_old: 3 For a dream cometh through the multitude of business,—and the voice of a dullard is with a multitude of words.

content: 4 When thou vowest a vow unto God do not defer to pay it, for there is no pleasure in dullards,—what thou vowest pay!
content_old: 4 When thou vowest a vow unto God do not defer to pay it, for there is no pleasure in dullards,—what thou vowest pay!

content: 5 Better that thou shouldest not vow,—than vow､ and not pay.
content_old: 5 Better that thou shouldest not vow,—than vow､ and not pay.

content: 6 Do not let thy mouth cause thy flesh to sin,—neither say thou､ before the messenger, that it was a mistake,—wherefore should God be indignant at thy voice, and destroy the work of thy hands?
content_old: 6 Do not let thy mouth cause thy flesh to sin,—neither say thou､ before the messenger, that it was a mistake,—wherefore should God be indignant at thy voice, and destroy the work of thy hands?

content: 7 For it was done amidst a multitude of dreams�� and vanities, and many words,—but towards God be thou reverent.
content_old: 7 For it was done amidst a multitude of dreams�� and vanities, and many words,—but towards God be thou reverent.

content: 8 If the oppression of the poor､ and the wresting of justice and righteousness thou see in the province do not be astonished over the matter,—for one high above the highest is watching, yea the Most High is over them.
content_old: 8 If the oppression of the poor､ and the wresting of justice and righteousness thou see in the province do not be astonished over the matter,—for one high above the highest is watching, yea the Most High is over them.

content: 9 And the profit of the earth is for all,—a king by the field is served.
content_old: 9 And the profit of the earth is for all,—a king by the field is served.

content: 10 He that loveth silver shall not be satisfied with silver nor he that loveth abundancewith revenue,—even this was vanity.
content_old: 10 He that loveth silver shall not be satisfied with silver nor he that loveth abundancewith revenue,—even this was vanity.

content: 11 When blessings are increased increased are the eaters thereof,—what profit､ then､ to the owner of them saving the sight of his eyes?
content_old: 11 When blessings are increased increased are the eaters thereof,—what profit､ then､ to the owner of them saving the sight of his eyes?

content: 12 Sweet the sleep of the labourer, whether little or much he eat,—but the surfeit of the rich man will not suffer him to sleep.
content_old: 12 Sweet the sleep of the labourer, whether little or much he eat,—but the surfeit of the rich man will not suffer him to sleep.

content: 13 Here was an incurable evil, I had seen under the sun,—riches kept by the owner thereof､ to his hurt;
content_old: 13 Here was an incurable evil, I had seen under the sun,—riches kept by the owner thereof､ to his hurt;

content: 14 and those riches perish､ by being ill employed,—and though he begetteth a son, yet is there in his hand nothing at all.
content_old: 14 and those riches perish､ by being ill employed,—and though he begetteth a son, yet is there in his hand nothing at all.

content: 15 As he came from his mother’s womb naked he again departeth､ as he came,—and nothing can he take of his toil, which he can carry in his hand.
content_old: 15 As he came from his mother’s womb naked he again departeth､ as he came,—and nothing can he take of his toil, which he can carry in his hand.

content: 16 Even this moreover､ is an incurable evil, altogether as he came so shall he depart,—what profit then shall he have who toileth for the wind?
content_old: 16 Even this moreover､ is an incurable evil, altogether as he came so shall he depart,—what profit then shall he have who toileth for the wind?

content: 17 Even all his days are spent in darkness and mourning,—and he is very morose､ and is sad and angry.
content_old: 17 Even all his days are spent in darkness and mourning,—and he is very morose､ and is sad and angry.

content: 18 Lo! what I myself have seen—Better that it should be excellent to eat and to drink and to see blessedness､ in all one’s toil wherein one toileth under the sun､ for the number of the days of his life､ in that God hath given it him､ for that is his portion:
content_old: 18 Lo! what I myself have seen—Better that it should be excellent to eat and to drink and to see blessedness､ in all one’s toil wherein one toileth under the sun､ for the number of the days of his life､ in that God hath given it him､ for that is his portion:

content: 19 yet as regardeth every man､ to whom God hath given wealth and goods､ and granted him power to eat thereof､ and to take his portion, and to find gladness in his toil this is the gift of God.
content_old: 19 yet as regardeth every man､ to whom God hath given wealth and goods､ and granted him power to eat thereof､ and to take his portion, and to find gladness in his toil this is the gift of God.

content: 1 Here was an evil, I had seen under the sun,—and it is common among men:
content_old: 1 Here was an evil, I had seen under the sun,—and it is common among men:

content: 2 A man to whom God giveth riches and gains and honour､ so that nothing doth he lack for his soul—of all that he craveth and yet God doth not give him power to eat thereof, but a man unknown eateth it,—this was vanity､ and an incurable evil it was.
content_old: 2 A man to whom God giveth riches and gains and honour､ so that nothing doth he lack for his soul—of all that he craveth and yet God doth not give him power to eat thereof, but a man unknown eateth it,—this was vanity､ and an incurable evil it was.

content: 3 Though a man should beget a hundred children､ and live many years so that many should be the days of his years､ but his own soul should not be satisfied with the good, and he should not even have a burial I said､ Better than he is an untimely birth!
content_old: 3 Though a man should beget a hundred children､ and live many years so that many should be the days of his years､ but his own soul should not be satisfied with the good, and he should not even have a burial I said､ Better than he is an untimely birth!

content: 4 For in vain it came in､ and in darkness it departeth,—and with darkness its name is covered:
content_old: 4 For in vain it came in､ and in darkness it departeth,—and with darkness its name is covered:

content: 5 even the sun it never saw､ nor aught did it know,—more quietness hath this than the other.
content_old: 5 even the sun it never saw､ nor aught did it know,—more quietness hath this than the other.

content: 6 Even though one hath lived a thousand years twice told yet good hath he not seen,—is it not unto one place that all are going?
content_old: 6 Even though one hath lived a thousand years twice told yet good hath he not seen,—is it not unto one place that all are going?

content: 7 All the toil of man is for his mouth,—though even the desirell is not satisfied!
content_old: 7 All the toil of man is for his mouth,—though even the desirell is not satisfied!

content: 8 For what profit hath the wise man､ over the dullard? What can the poor man know—so as to walk before the living?
content_old: 8 For what profit hath the wise man､ over the dullard? What can the poor man know—so as to walk before the living?

content: 9 Better what the eyes behold､ than the wandering of desire,—even this was vanity､ and a feeding on wind.
content_old: 9 Better what the eyes behold､ than the wandering of desire,—even this was vanity､ and a feeding on wind.

content: 10 Whatsoever one may be long ago was he called by his name, and it is known that it is—Son of Earth,—he cannot､ therefore､ contend with one stronger than he.
content_old: 10 Whatsoever one may be long ago was he called by his name, and it is known that it is—Son of Earth,—he cannot､ therefore､ contend with one stronger than he.

content: 11 Seeing there are things in abundance which make vanity abound what profit hath man?
content_old: 11 Seeing there are things in abundance which make vanity abound what profit hath man?

content: 1 Better a name､ than precious ointment,— And the day of death, than the day of one’s birth.
content_old: 1 Better a name､ than precious ointment,— And the day of death, than the day of one’s birth.

content: 2 Better to go to the house of mourning､ than to go to the house of banqueting, For that is the end of all men,— And the living should take it to his heart.
content_old: 2 Better to go to the house of mourning､ than to go to the house of banqueting, For that is the end of all men,— And the living should take it to his heart.

content: 3 Better is grief than laughter,— For by the marring of the face amended is the heart.
content_old: 3 Better is grief than laughter,— For by the marring of the face amended is the heart.

content: 4 The heart of the wise is in the house of mourning, But the heart of dullards in the house of mirth.
content_old: 4 The heart of the wise is in the house of mourning, But the heart of dullards in the house of mirth.

content: 5 Better to hear the rebuke of the wise､ Than for any man to hear the song of dullards.
content_old: 5 Better to hear the rebuke of the wise､ Than for any man to hear the song of dullards.

content: 6 For as the crackling of thorns under a pot so is the laughter of the dullard,— Even this then､ was vanity.
content_old: 6 For as the crackling of thorns under a pot so is the laughter of the dullard,— Even this then､ was vanity.

content: 7 For oppression maddeneth the wise,— And a bribe destroyeth the understanding .
content_old: 7 For oppression maddeneth the wise,— And a bribe destroyeth the understanding .

content: 8 Better the latter end of a thing､ than the beginning thereof,— Better a patient spirit､ than a haughty spirit.
content_old: 8 Better the latter end of a thing､ than the beginning thereof,— Better a patient spirit､ than a haughty spirit.

content: 9 Do not be rash in thy spirit､ to be indignant,— For indignation in the bosom of dullards doth remain.
content_old: 9 Do not be rash in thy spirit､ to be indignant,— For indignation in the bosom of dullards doth remain.

content: 10 Do not say､ What hath happened, that the former days were better､ than these? For not wisely askest thou concerning this.
content_old: 10 Do not say､ What hath happened, that the former days were better､ than these? For not wisely askest thou concerning this.

content: 11 Good is wisdom､ with an inheritance,—and a profit､ to such as see the sun.
content_old: 11 Good is wisdom､ with an inheritance,—and a profit､ to such as see the sun.

content: 12 For a protection is wisdom､ and a protection is silver,—but the advantage of knowledge is, that wisdom giveth life to the possessors thereof.
content_old: 12 For a protection is wisdom､ and a protection is silver,—but the advantage of knowledge is, that wisdom giveth life to the possessors thereof.

content: 13 Consider the work of God,—for who can straighten what he hath bent?
content_old: 13 Consider the work of God,—for who can straighten what he hath bent?

content: 14 In the day of prosperity be joyful, But in the day of misfortune consider,— Even the one equally with the other hath God made, to the end man might find out—after him—nothing.
content_old: 14 In the day of prosperity be joyful, But in the day of misfortune consider,— Even the one equally with the other hath God made, to the end man might find out—after him—nothing.

content: 15 Everything had I seen､ in my days of vanity,— Here was a righteous man､ perishing in his righteousness, And there was a lawless man､ continuing long in his wickedness.
content_old: 15 Everything had I seen､ in my days of vanity,— Here was a righteous man､ perishing in his righteousness, And there was a lawless man､ continuing long in his wickedness.

content: 16 Do not become so very righteous, neither count thyself wise beyond measure,—wherefore shouldst thou destroy thyself?
content_old: 16 Do not become so very righteous, neither count thyself wise beyond measure,—wherefore shouldst thou destroy thyself?

content: 17 Do not be so very lawless､ neither become thou foolish,—wherefore shouldst thou die､ before thy time?
content_old: 17 Do not be so very lawless､ neither become thou foolish,—wherefore shouldst thou die､ before thy time?

content: 18 It is well that thou shouldst lay fast hold of this, but even from the other do not withdraw thy hand,—for he that revereth God shall come forth out of them all.
content_old: 18 It is well that thou shouldst lay fast hold of this, but even from the other do not withdraw thy hand,—for he that revereth God shall come forth out of them all.

content: 19 Wisdom bringeth more strength to a wise man, than ten heroes､ that are in the city､
content_old: 19 Wisdom bringeth more strength to a wise man, than ten heroes､ that are in the city､

content: 20 For as for men there is none righteous in the earth, that doeth good､ and sinneth not.
content_old: 20 For as for men there is none righteous in the earth, that doeth good､ and sinneth not.

content: 21 Moreover not to all the words which men speak do thou apply thy heart,—lest thou hear thine own servant reviling thee!
content_old: 21 Moreover not to all the words which men speak do thou apply thy heart,—lest thou hear thine own servant reviling thee!

content: 22 For truly many times thy heart knoweth,—that even thou thyself hast reviled others.
content_old: 22 For truly many times thy heart knoweth,—that even thou thyself hast reviled others.

content: 23 All this have I proved by wisdom,—I said､ I will be wise, but that was far from me.
content_old: 23 All this have I proved by wisdom,—I said､ I will be wise, but that was far from me.

content: 24 Far away is that which hath been,—and deep､ deep, who can find it out?
content_old: 24 Far away is that which hath been,—and deep､ deep, who can find it out?

content: 25 Resolved I in my heart､ to know and search out, and to seek wisdom､ and a conclusion,—and to know lawlessness to be stupidity, and folly to be madness.
content_old: 25 Resolved I in my heart､ to know and search out, and to seek wisdom､ and a conclusion,—and to know lawlessness to be stupidity, and folly to be madness.

content: 26 I could indeed find､ to be more bitter than death the woman､ whose heart is snares and nets､ and her hands bonds,—whoso is pleasing before God shall escape from her, but he that sinneth shall be captured by her.
content_old: 26 I could indeed find､ to be more bitter than death the woman､ whose heart is snares and nets､ and her hands bonds,—whoso is pleasing before God shall escape from her, but he that sinneth shall be captured by her.

content: 27 See! this have I found, saith the Proclaimer counting one by one､ to find a conclusion;
content_old: 27 See! this have I found, saith the Proclaimer counting one by one､ to find a conclusion;

content: 28 what my soul still sought yet I found not,—one man out of a thousand have I found, but a woman among all these have I not found.
content_old: 28 what my soul still sought yet I found not,—one man out of a thousand have I found, but a woman among all these have I not found.

content: 1 Who is really a wise man, And who knoweth the interpretation of a thing? The wisdom of a man lighteth up his countenance, But by defiance of countenance one is disfigured.
content_old: 1 Who is really a wise man, And who knoweth the interpretation of a thing? The wisdom of a man lighteth up his countenance, But by defiance of countenance one is disfigured.

content: 2 I said ､ The bidding of the king observe thou, even out of regard to the oath of God.
content_old: 2 I said ､ The bidding of the king observe thou, even out of regard to the oath of God.

content: 3 Not rashly from his presence shouldst thou go: do not take thy stand in a vexatious thing,—for whatsoever he pleaseth he will do.
content_old: 3 Not rashly from his presence shouldst thou go: do not take thy stand in a vexatious thing,—for whatsoever he pleaseth he will do.

content: 4 Where the word of a king is there is power,—who then may say to him､ What wouldst thou do?
content_old: 4 Where the word of a king is there is power,—who then may say to him､ What wouldst thou do?

content: 5 He that observeth the commandment will not notice a vexatious thing,—and of time and manner will the heart of the wise take note.
content_old: 5 He that observeth the commandment will not notice a vexatious thing,—and of time and manner will the heart of the wise take note.

content: 6 For to every pursuit there is a time and a manner,—when the vexation of man is great concerning it.
content_old: 6 For to every pursuit there is a time and a manner,—when the vexation of man is great concerning it.

content: 7 For there is no one who knoweth what shall be,—for when it shall be who will tell him?
content_old: 7 For there is no one who knoweth what shall be,—for when it shall be who will tell him?

content: 8 No man hath power over the spirit､ to retain the spirit, and none hath power over the day of death, and there is no furlough in war,—neither shall lawlessness deliver them who are given thereto.
content_old: 8 No man hath power over the spirit､ to retain the spirit, and none hath power over the day of death, and there is no furlough in war,—neither shall lawlessness deliver them who are given thereto.

content: 9 All this had I seen､ and tried to apply my heart to every work which was done under the sun,—at such time as one man had power over another man､ to his hurt.
content_old: 9 All this had I seen､ and tried to apply my heart to every work which was done under the sun,—at such time as one man had power over another man､ to his hurt.

content: 10 And thereupon I considered the lawless when buried､ when they had entered their graves ､ that from the place of the Holy One they used to go and boast in the city that they had so done,—even this was vanity.
content_old: 10 And thereupon I considered the lawless when buried､ when they had entered their graves ､ that from the place of the Holy One they used to go and boast in the city that they had so done,—even this was vanity.

content: 11 Because sentence against a wicked work is not executed speedily—on this account the heart of the sons of men is fully set within them､ to commit wickedness.
content_old: 11 Because sentence against a wicked work is not executed speedily—on this account the heart of the sons of men is fully set within them､ to commit wickedness.

content: 12 Though a sinner be committing wickedness a hundred times､ and continuing long in his own way yet I surely know that it shall be well to them who revere God, who stand in awe before him;
content_old: 12 Though a sinner be committing wickedness a hundred times､ and continuing long in his own way yet I surely know that it shall be well to them who revere God, who stand in awe before him;

content: 13 but well shall it not be to the lawless man, neither shall he lengthen out his days like a shadow,—because he standeth not in awe before God.
content_old: 13 but well shall it not be to the lawless man, neither shall he lengthen out his days like a shadow,—because he standeth not in awe before God.

content: 14 Here was a vain thing which was done upon the earth—that there were righteous men unto whom it happened according to the work of the lawless, and there were lawless men､ unto whom it happened according to the work of the righteous,—I said､ that even this was vanity.
content_old: 14 Here was a vain thing which was done upon the earth—that there were righteous men unto whom it happened according to the work of the lawless, and there were lawless men､ unto whom it happened according to the work of the righteous,—I said､ that even this was vanity.

content: 15 Then extolled I､ gladness, in that there was nothing better for a man､ under the sun, than to eat and to drink､ and to be glad,—since that should tarry with him in his toil､ for the days of his life which God had given him under the sun.
content_old: 15 Then extolled I､ gladness, in that there was nothing better for a man､ under the sun, than to eat and to drink､ and to be glad,—since that should tarry with him in his toil､ for the days of his life which God had given him under the sun.

content: 16 When I gave my heart､ to know wisdom, and to consider the business that was done upon the earth then surely by day and by night there was one who suffered not his eyes to sleep.
content_old: 16 When I gave my heart､ to know wisdom, and to consider the business that was done upon the earth then surely by day and by night there was one who suffered not his eyes to sleep.

content: 1 For unto all this I applied my heart､ and my heart considered all this, that the righteous and the wise and their servants were in the hand of God,—neither love nor hatred could any man know, every one was before Him.
content_old: 1 For unto all this I applied my heart､ and my heart considered all this, that the righteous and the wise and their servants were in the hand of God,—neither love nor hatred could any man know, every one was before Him.

content: 2 Every one was like every one else､ one destiny had the righteous and the lawless､ the good and the pure and the impure, and he that sacrificed､ and he that did not sacrifice,—as the good man so the sinner, he that took an oath as he who of an oath stood in fear.
content_old: 2 Every one was like every one else､ one destiny had the righteous and the lawless､ the good and the pure and the impure, and he that sacrificed､ and he that did not sacrifice,—as the good man so the sinner, he that took an oath as he who of an oath stood in fear.

content: 3 This was a misfortune in all that was done under the sun, that one destiny had they all,—yea also the heart of the sons of men was full of wickedness､ and madness was in their heart､ while they lived, and after that they went unto the dead.
content_old: 3 This was a misfortune in all that was done under the sun, that one destiny had they all,—yea also the heart of the sons of men was full of wickedness､ and madness was in their heart､ while they lived, and after that they went unto the dead.

content: 4 For whosoever was united to all the living for him there was hope,—inasmuch as a living dog fared better than a dead lion.
content_old: 4 For whosoever was united to all the living for him there was hope,—inasmuch as a living dog fared better than a dead lion.

content: 5 For the living knew that they should die,—but the dead knew not anything､ neither had they any longer a reward, because forgotten was their memory.
content_old: 5 For the living knew that they should die,—but the dead knew not anything､ neither had they any longer a reward, because forgotten was their memory.

content: 6 Both their love and their hatred and their envy already had perished,—and portion had they none any longer､ unto times age-abiding, in aught that was done under the sun.
content_old: 6 Both their love and their hatred and their envy already had perished,—and portion had they none any longer､ unto times age-abiding, in aught that was done under the sun.

content: 7 Go thy way—eat､ with gladness､ thy food, and drink､ with a happy heart､ thy wine,—when already God is well pleased with thy works.
content_old: 7 Go thy way—eat､ with gladness､ thy food, and drink､ with a happy heart､ thy wine,—when already God is well pleased with thy works.

content: 8 Continually let thy garments be white,—and ointment upon thy head let it not be lacking.
content_old: 8 Continually let thy garments be white,—and ointment upon thy head let it not be lacking.

content: 9 Enjoy life､ with thy wife whom thou lovest､ all the days of thy life of vanity, which he hath given thee under the sun, all thy days of vanity,—for that is thy portion in life, and in thy toil wherewith thou art toiling under the sun.
content_old: 9 Enjoy life､ with thy wife whom thou lovest､ all the days of thy life of vanity, which he hath given thee under the sun, all thy days of vanity,—for that is thy portion in life, and in thy toil wherewith thou art toiling under the sun.

content: 10 Whatsoever thy hand findeth to do with thy might do,—for there is no work nor calculation nor knowledge nor wisdom, in hades､ whither thou art going.
content_old: 10 Whatsoever thy hand findeth to do with thy might do,—for there is no work nor calculation nor knowledge nor wisdom, in hades､ whither thou art going.

content: 11 I again saw under the sun, that not to the swift was the race､ nor to the strong the battle､ nay! nor to the wise food､ nor yet to the intelligent riches, nor even to the well-informed comeliness,—for time and accident happened to them all.
content_old: 11 I again saw under the sun, that not to the swift was the race､ nor to the strong the battle､ nay! nor to the wise food､ nor yet to the intelligent riches, nor even to the well-informed comeliness,—for time and accident happened to them all.

content: 12 For, indeed､ man could not know his own time､ like fishes which were caught in a cruel net, and like little birds which were caught in a trap,—like them were ensnared the sons of men, by a time of misfortune､ when it fell upon them suddenly.
content_old: 12 For, indeed､ man could not know his own time､ like fishes which were caught in a cruel net, and like little birds which were caught in a trap,—like them were ensnared the sons of men, by a time of misfortune､ when it fell upon them suddenly.

content: 13 Even this had I seen of wisdom､ under the sun,—and of great import was the same unto me:—
content_old: 13 Even this had I seen of wisdom､ under the sun,—and of great import was the same unto me:—

content: 14 A little city, and men therein few,—and there came against it a great king､ and surrounded it, and built against it large siege-works;
content_old: 14 A little city, and men therein few,—and there came against it a great king､ and surrounded it, and built against it large siege-works;

content: 15 but there was found therein､ a man､ poor but wise, and he delivered the city by his wisdom,—yet no one remembered that poor man.
content_old: 15 but there was found therein､ a man､ poor but wise, and he delivered the city by his wisdom,—yet no one remembered that poor man.

content: 16 Then said I, Better is wisdom than strength,—although the wisdom of the poor man be despised, and his words not heard.
content_old: 16 Then said I, Better is wisdom than strength,—although the wisdom of the poor man be despised, and his words not heard.

content: 17 The words of the wise in quietness are heard,—beyond the outcry of one who ruleth over dullards.
content_old: 17 The words of the wise in quietness are heard,—beyond the outcry of one who ruleth over dullards.

content: 1 Dead flies cause to stink and ferment､ the oil of the perfumer,— More costly than wisdom or honour is a little folly.
content_old: 1 Dead flies cause to stink and ferment､ the oil of the perfumer,— More costly than wisdom or honour is a little folly.

content: 2 The sense of the wise is on his right hand,— But the sense of the dullard on his left:
content_old: 2 The sense of the wise is on his right hand,— But the sense of the dullard on his left:

content: 3 Yea even by the way､ as the foolish man walketh along his sense faileth him—and he telleth everyone that foolish is he!
content_old: 3 Yea even by the way､ as the foolish man walketh along his sense faileth him—and he telleth everyone that foolish is he!

content: 4 If the spirit of a ruler riseth up against thee thy place do not leave,—for gentleness pacifieth such as have greatly erred.
content_old: 4 If the spirit of a ruler riseth up against thee thy place do not leave,—for gentleness pacifieth such as have greatly erred.

content: 5 Here was a misfortune I had seen under the sun,—a veritable mistake that was going forth from the presence of one who had power:
content_old: 5 Here was a misfortune I had seen under the sun,—a veritable mistake that was going forth from the presence of one who had power:

content: 6 Folly placed in great dignity,— While the rich in a low place took their seat:
content_old: 6 Folly placed in great dignity,— While the rich in a low place took their seat:

content: 7 I had seen servants upon horses,— And rulers walking like servants､ on the ground.
content_old: 7 I had seen servants upon horses,— And rulers walking like servants､ on the ground.

content: 8 He that diggeth a pit thereinto may fall,— And he that breaketh through a hedge there may bite him a serpent.
content_old: 8 He that diggeth a pit thereinto may fall,— And he that breaketh through a hedge there may bite him a serpent.

content: 9 He that removeth stones may be hurt therewith,— And he that cleaveth wood may be endangered thereby.
content_old: 9 He that removeth stones may be hurt therewith,— And he that cleaveth wood may be endangered thereby.

content: 10 If blunt be the iron､ and himself hath not sharpened the edge then much force must he apply,—but an advantage for giving success is wisdom.
content_old: 10 If blunt be the iron､ and himself hath not sharpened the edge then much force must he apply,—but an advantage for giving success is wisdom.

content: 11 If a serpent will bite､ unless he is charmed Then there is nothing better for him that owneth a tongue.
content_old: 11 If a serpent will bite､ unless he is charmed Then there is nothing better for him that owneth a tongue.

content: 12 The words of a wise man’s mouth are pleasant,— But the lips of a dullard will swallow him up:
content_old: 12 The words of a wise man’s mouth are pleasant,— But the lips of a dullard will swallow him up:

content: 13 The beginning of the words of his mouth is folly,— But the latter end of his speech is mischievous madness.
content_old: 13 The beginning of the words of his mouth is folly,— But the latter end of his speech is mischievous madness.

content: 14 Yet a foolish man multiplieth words,— Though no man knoweth that which hath been, And that which shall be after him who can tell him?
content_old: 14 Yet a foolish man multiplieth words,— Though no man knoweth that which hath been, And that which shall be after him who can tell him?

content: 15 The toil of dullards shall weary a man, That he knoweth not how to go into the city.
content_old: 15 The toil of dullards shall weary a man, That he knoweth not how to go into the city.

content: 16 Alas! for thee､ O land, when thy king is a boy,— And thy rulers in the morning do eat:
content_old: 16 Alas! for thee､ O land, when thy king is a boy,— And thy rulers in the morning do eat:

content: 17 How happy art thou､ O land, when thy king is a son of nobles,— And thy rulers in season do eat, For strength､ and not for debauchery.
content_old: 17 How happy art thou､ O land, when thy king is a son of nobles,— And thy rulers in season do eat, For strength､ and not for debauchery.

content: 18 By two lazy arms the framework sinketh in,— And by the hanging down of the hands the house may leak.
content_old: 18 By two lazy arms the framework sinketh in,— And by the hanging down of the hands the house may leak.

content: 19 Merrily people make bread, And wine gladdeneth life,— But money answereth all things.
content_old: 19 Merrily people make bread, And wine gladdeneth life,— But money answereth all things.

content: 1 Cast thy bread-corn､ upon the face of the waters,— For after many days shalt thou find it:
content_old: 1 Cast thy bread-corn､ upon the face of the waters,— For after many days shalt thou find it:

content: 2 Give a portion to seven､ yea even to eight,— For thou canst not know, what there shall be of misfortune､ upon the earth.
content_old: 2 Give a portion to seven､ yea even to eight,— For thou canst not know, what there shall be of misfortune､ upon the earth.

content: 3 If the clouds be filled with a downpour Upon the earth will they empty themselves, And if a tree fall in the south or in the north In the place where the tree falleth there will it be found.
content_old: 3 If the clouds be filled with a downpour Upon the earth will they empty themselves, And if a tree fall in the south or in the north In the place where the tree falleth there will it be found.

content: 4 He that observeth the wind will not sow,— And he that watcheth the clouds will not reap.
content_old: 4 He that observeth the wind will not sow,— And he that watcheth the clouds will not reap.

content: 5 Just as thou knowest not what is the way of the spirit, when the body is in the womb of her that is with child Even so canst thou not know the work of God, who maketh all.
content_old: 5 Just as thou knowest not what is the way of the spirit, when the body is in the womb of her that is with child Even so canst thou not know the work of God, who maketh all.

content: 6 In the morning sow thy seed, And until evening do not withhold thy hand,— For thou knowest not— Whether shall thrive､ either this or that, Or whether both alike shall be fruitful.
content_old: 6 In the morning sow thy seed, And until evening do not withhold thy hand,— For thou knowest not— Whether shall thrive､ either this or that, Or whether both alike shall be fruitful.

content: 7 Truly sweet is the light,— And pleasant to the eyes to see the sun:
content_old: 7 Truly sweet is the light,— And pleasant to the eyes to see the sun:

content: 8 But though many years a man live Through them all let him rejoice; Yet let him remember the days of darkness, For many they may be､ all that cometh may be vanity.
content_old: 8 But though many years a man live Through them all let him rejoice; Yet let him remember the days of darkness, For many they may be､ all that cometh may be vanity.

content: 9 Rejoice､ O young man､ in thy youth､ And let thy heart gladden thee in the days of thine early manhood, And walk thou— In the ways of thine own heart, And in that which is seen by thine own eyes,— Yet know､ that for all these things Will God bring thee into judgment.
content_old: 9 Rejoice､ O young man､ in thy youth､ And let thy heart gladden thee in the days of thine early manhood, And walk thou— In the ways of thine own heart, And in that which is seen by thine own eyes,— Yet know､ that for all these things Will God bring thee into judgment.

content: 1 Yet remember thy Creator, in the days of thy vigour,— Or ever come in､ the days of discomfort, And the years arrive､ in which thou shalt say— I have､ in them､ no pleasure;
content_old: 1 Yet remember thy Creator, in the days of thy vigour,— Or ever come in､ the days of discomfort, And the years arrive､ in which thou shalt say— I have､ in them､ no pleasure;

content: 2 Or ever be darkened— The sun､ and the light, and the moon､ and the stars,— And the clouds return after a downpour of rain;
content_old: 2 Or ever be darkened— The sun､ and the light, and the moon､ and the stars,— And the clouds return after a downpour of rain;

content: 3 In the day when the keepers of the house shall tremble, And the men of might bow themselves,— And the grinders cease because they are few, And they who look through the windows are darkened;
content_old: 3 In the day when the keepers of the house shall tremble, And the men of might bow themselves,— And the grinders cease because they are few, And they who look through the windows are darkened;

content: 4 And the doors in the street be closed, When the sound of the mill become low,— And one rise at the chirp of a small bird, And low-voiced be all the daughters of song;
content_old: 4 And the doors in the street be closed, When the sound of the mill become low,— And one rise at the chirp of a small bird, And low-voiced be all the daughters of song;

content: 5 Yea at what is high they be in fear､ And there be terrors in the way, And the almond be rejected､ And the grasshopper drag itself along, And desire perish,— For man is going to his age-abiding home, When the wailers shall go round in the streets;
content_old: 5 Yea at what is high they be in fear､ And there be terrors in the way, And the almond be rejected､ And the grasshopper drag itself along, And desire perish,— For man is going to his age-abiding home, When the wailers shall go round in the streets;

content: 6 Or ever the silver cord be loosed, Or the golden bowl be broken,— Or the bucket by the fountain be shivered, Or the wheel at the well be broken;
content_old: 6 Or ever the silver cord be loosed, Or the golden bowl be broken,— Or the bucket by the fountain be shivered, Or the wheel at the well be broken;

content: 7 And the dust return to the earth､ as it was,— And the spirit return unto God､ who gave it.
content_old: 7 And the dust return to the earth､ as it was,— And the spirit return unto God､ who gave it.

content: 8 Vanity of vanities､ saith the Proclaimer､ all is vanity.
content_old: 8 Vanity of vanities､ saith the Proclaimer､ all is vanity.

content: 9 Besides that the Proclaimer being wise,—still further taught knowledge unto the people, and weighed and searched､ arranged proverbs in abundance.
content_old: 9 Besides that the Proclaimer being wise,—still further taught knowledge unto the people, and weighed and searched､ arranged proverbs in abundance.

content: 10 The Proclaimer sought to find out words giving delight, And to note down rightly､ the words of truth.
content_old: 10 The Proclaimer sought to find out words giving delight, And to note down rightly､ the words of truth.

content: 11 The words of the wise are as goads, Yea as driven nails their well-ordered sayings,— Given from one shepherd.
content_old: 11 The words of the wise are as goads, Yea as driven nails their well-ordered sayings,— Given from one shepherd.

content: 12 And besides from them my son, be admonished,— Of making many books there is no end, And much study is a weariness of the flesh.
content_old: 12 And besides from them my son, be admonished,— Of making many books there is no end, And much study is a weariness of the flesh.

content: 13 The conclusion of the matter—the whole let us hear,— Towards God be reverent､ And his commandments observe, For this concerneth all mankind.
content_old: 13 The conclusion of the matter—the whole let us hear,— Towards God be reverent､ And his commandments observe, For this concerneth all mankind.
